title: No Bing results for Searx (but for SearxNG)
body:
The public instances Searx instances don't seem return any results for Bing but SearxNG instances do. I think the situation has been the same for days or even weeks.

I tried out several searx and searxng instances: https://searx.space/

### Searx

Example Searx instance: https://searx.roflcopter.fr/ (1.1.0-53-c647b55e)
[Bing search in roflcopter.fr](https://searx.roflcopter.fr/search?q=%21bi%20foo&categories=none&language=en-US) gave "Sorry! we didn't find any results."

### SearxNG

Example SearxNG instances: https://northboot.xyz/ (2023.2.4+7320b0c7)
[Bing search in northboot.xyz](https://northboot.xyz/search?q=%21bi+foo&category_general=1&language=en-US&time_range=&safesearch=1&theme=simple) gave a pageful of results.

### Suggestion

Might the fix be included in the [SearxNG commit list](https://github.com/searxng/searxng/commits/master/searx/engines/bing.py)? There are several references to Bing that are not included in [Searx commit list](https://github.com/searx/searx/commits/master/searx/engines/bing.py)
There is a big diff between https://raw.githubusercontent.com/searxng/searxng/master/searx/engines/bing.py and https://raw.githubusercontent.com/searx/searx/master/searx/engines/bing.py

title: Fix pages on Wiby
remove distutils usage
body:
In Python 3.10 and 3.11, distutils has been formally marked as deprecated. Code that imports distutils will no longer work from Python 3.12.

`searx_extra/update/update_firefox_version.py` still uses distutils. Maybe its use of `distutils.version` can be replaced by the `packaging` module?

See https://peps.python.org/pep-0632/

title: DuckDuckGo blocked
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**

Running off `master` at commit 117dbd462f39fb4c

**How did you install Searx?**

Installed and run manually from source (not docker)

**What happened?**

After starting searx, the first search says in the UI that duckduckgo was blocked. The `debug: True` logging shows:

```
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://lite.duckduckgo.com:443 "POST /lite HTTP/1.1" 403 None
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://www.bing.com:443 "GET /search?q=language%3AEN+hello+world&first=1 HTTP/1.1" 200 None       
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://search.yahoo.com:443 "GET /search?p=hello+world&ei=UTF-8&fl=1&vl=lang_en&btf=&fr2=time&age=&b=1&xargs=0 HTTP/1.1" 200 None                                                                                                 
DEBUG:searx:duckduckgo: ErrorContext('/home/searx/searx/searx/search/processors/online.py', 96, "response = req(params['url'], **request_args)", 'searx.exceptions.SearxEngineAccessDeniedException', None, ('HTTP error 403',))
ERROR:searx.search.processor.online:engine duckduckgo : Searx is blocked                                                        
Traceback (most recent call last):                                                                                              
  File "/home/searx/searx/searx/search/processors/online.py", line 144, in search                                               
    search_results = self._search_basic(query, params)                                                                          
  File "/home/searx/searx/searx/search/processors/online.py", line 124, in _search_basic                                        
    response = self._send_http_request(params)                                                                                  
  File "/home/searx/searx/searx/search/processors/online.py", line 96, in _send_http_request
    response = req(params['url'], **request_args)                                                                               
  File "/home/searx/searx/searx/poolrequests.py", line 223, in post                                                             
    return request('post', url, data=data, **kwargs)                                                                            
  File "/home/searx/searx/searx/poolrequests.py", line 202, in request                                                          
    raise_for_httperror(response)                                                                                               
  File "/home/searx/searx/searx/raise_for_httperror.py", line 62, in raise_for_httperror
    raise SearxEngineAccessDeniedException(message='HTTP error ' + str(resp.status_code),
searx.exceptions.SearxEngineAccessDeniedException: HTTP error 403, suspended_time=86400
```

as per https://github.com/searx/searx/blob/117dbd462f39fb4cc2f12e9f7b9acf8d3fff419b/searx/search/processors/online.py#L195-L198

The block message no longer appears in the UI after the first search. I'm assuming searx recognizes the block and enacts a one-day (86400-second) cooldown.

**How To Reproduce**

Of course, this is specific to my instance, which I am not willing to share. Nevertheless, I hope to be able to resolve it with some dialogue.

**Expected behavior**

DDG is not blocked

**Screenshots & Logs**

See above.

**Additional context**

Is there anything I can do to lift the block? Should I disable the DDG engine for a few days?

title: Startpage is blocking searx - startpage engine doesn't work

title: Using single apostrophe causes a "search error"
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
1.1.0-27-bf0a583f

in order to fetch the latest commit ID:

git log -1
``` 
If you are using searx-docker then look at the bottom of the Searx page
and check for the version after "Powered by searx"

Please also stipulate if you are using a forked version of Searx and
include a link to the fork source code.
-->
**How did you install Searx?**
searx-docker. Specifically using docker-compose and running ``docker-compose up``.
Compose file:
```yaml
version: '3.3'
services:
    searx:
        volumes:
            - /mnt/storage1/configs/searx:/etc/searx
        ports:
            - 9999:8080
        environment:
            - BASE_URL=http://localhost:9999/
        image: searx/searx
        restart: unless-stopped
```
<!-- Did you install Searx using the official wiki or using searx-docker
or manually by executing the searx/webapp.py file? -->
**What happened?**
Using a single apostrophe in a word (for example, "What's") causes a search error
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
**How To Reproduce**
Use any single apostrophe in a search query

Should return results, instead of an error.

**Additional context**

title: filtron.sh installation issues
body:
**Version**
_commit_ 117dbd462f39fb4cc2f12e9f7b9acf8d3fff419b
GO version: go1.13.5 linux/amd64


I followed the step-by-step guide and the installation wiki page side by side, Searx installed fine however `filtron.sh install all` doesn't seem to go well as there is no `/usr/local/filtron/go-apps/bin` directory, even though `$GOENV` is set up correctly.

During the installation there seems to be the following issue:
```
# github.com/klauspost/compress/flate
go-apps/src/github.com/klauspost/compress/flate/deflate.go:135:23: cannot convert d.window (type []byte) to type *[32768]byte
go-apps/src/github.com/klauspost/compress/flate/deflate.go:135:56: cannot convert d.window[windowSize:] (type []byte) to type *[32768]byte
go-apps/src/github.com/klauspost/compress/flate/fast_encoder.go:93:28: cannot convert e.hist (type []byte) to type *[32768]byte
go-apps/src/github.com/klauspost/compress/flate/fast_encoder.go:93:63: cannot convert e.hist[offset:] (type []byte) to type *[32768]byte
go-apps/src/github.com/klauspost/compress/flate/huffman_bit_writer.go:794:17: cannot convert w.literalFreq[:] (type []uint16) to type *[256]uint16
go-apps/src/github.com/klauspost/compress/flate/huffman_bit_writer.go:796:16: cannot convert w.literalFreq[256:] (type []uint16) to type *[32]uint16
```

**How To Reproduce**
Simply run `./filtron.sh install all`

**Expected behavior**
Installation of Filtron and the activation of the Systemd unit.

**Additional context**
Installing it in a Debian11 LXC container, used pip and virtualenv.

I update quarterly and experiencing this issue for half a year now (3 mo ago I've decided to skip one update).

title: Couldn't find correct source of a featured snippet content
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
2022.08.23

**How did you install Searx?**
Reproducible on [searx.be](https://searx.be) instance.

**What happened?**
For some keyword searches source of Google's featured snippet content is missing from search result entirely.

**How To Reproduce**
- Search for ["apply dijkstra's algorithm with negative edge weight cycle"](https://searx.be/search?q=apply%20dijkstra%27s%20algorithm%20with%20negative%20edge%20weight%20cycle&categories=general) on [searx.be](https://searx.be) instance.
- Look for source of the snippet result i.e. [Why doesn't Dijkstra's algorithm work for negative weight ...](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13159337/why-doesnt-dijkstras-algorithm-work-for-negative-weight-edges) in the search results.

**Actual behavior**
Actual source of the featured snippet (i.e. [Why doesn't Dijkstra's algorithm work for negative weight ...](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/13159337/why-doesnt-dijkstras-algorithm-work-for-negative-weight-edges)) is missing from search results entirely.

**Expected behavior**
Either source of the featured snippet should be present inside the Searx's infobox or it should be first search result.

**Screenshots & Logs**
Google search result:

![google](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28824347/187061917-b7019068-35f2-4792-845a-6a3366a072f5.png)

Searx.be search result:
![searx](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28824347/187061988-aab4c87a-b46e-40b9-ad3e-62836bb923b1.png)


**Additional context**
Some more keywords for which snippet's source is missing.

| Keyword | Snippet's Source|
| ----------- | ---------------------- |
|[dijkstra's algorithm on negative edge weight cycle](https://searx.be/search?q=dijkstra%27s%20algorithm%20on%20negative%20edge%20weight%20cycle&categories=general)|[1 Negative Edge Weights 2 Bellman-Ford Algorithm](http://web.stanford.edu/class/archive/cs/cs161/cs161.1176/Lectures/CS161Lecture11.5.pdf)|
|[why does dijkstra fail for negative weights](https://searx.be/search?q=why%20does%20dijkstra%20fail%20for%20negative%20weights&categories=general)|[Why does Dijkstra's algorithm fail on negative weights?](https://www.codingninjas.com/codestudio/library/why-does-dijkstra-s-algorithm-fail-on-negative-weights)|

title: "Internal Server Error" after OS upgrade to Debian 11/Bullseye
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
<!-- If you are running on master branch using git execute this command
in order to fetch the latest commit ID:-->
```
(searx-py3env) searx@vm-searx:~/searx-src$ git log -1
commit 16d43fe8d4aef7bc9387d38d1e22aacfc3d04f15 (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD)
Author: Ben Collerson <bencollerson@gmail.com>
Date:   Wed Jul 13 00:23:44 2022 +1000

    [fix] keyboard hints for category tabs (#1187) (#3276)
    
    Category tabs issue: hints don't see category tabs
    [qutebrowser] #1187
(searx-py3env) searx@vm-searx:~/searx-src$ 
``` 

**How did you install Searx?**
<!-- Did you install Searx using the official wiki or using searx-docker
or manually by executing the searx/webapp.py file? -->

Following https://searx.github.io/searx/admin/installation-searx.html (I think some years ago under Debian 9) and upgraded it under Debian 10 following https://searx.github.io/searx/admin/update-searx.html recently before uprading to Debian 11.

title: Video search when using either Bing or Google doesn't get you past the first page
body:
This is an universal issue with Searx which strangely has never been noticed although it's so obvious when you start messing around with the settings and engine selection. Get a searx instance where bing & google work on video search and search for anything. You will notice now that when you go the next page for more results, the same results that were on the first page are being repeated. In other words, you can't get more results.

Please fix this issue, we should be able to get as many results as we wish. There is nothing technical truly making this impossible, it can be done.

title: Bing engine returns unsanitized URLs
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
<!-- If you are running on master branch using git execute this command
in order to fetch the latest commit ID:
```
git log -1
``` 
If you are using searx-docker then look at the bottom of the Searx page
and check for the version after "Powered by searx"

Please also stipulate if you are using a forked version of Searx and
include a link to the fork source code.
-->

Docker, version `1.0.0-372-6ffa70d8`

**How did you install Searx?**
<!-- Did you install Searx using the official wiki or using searx-docker
or manually by executing the searx/webapp.py file? -->

Docker Compose

**What happened?**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->

The URLs in results from the Bing engine are not sanitized. For example:

```
https://www.bing.com/ck/a?!&&p=c4b4301ae7afbd0a1071c3cfeb006528b245f72840bdd2cfb45fa713e8e4233aJmltdHM9MTY1Mzc5NDI2MSZpZ3VpZD01YjM5NjkwMC1kYTU5LTQ3NjktYThhZC0wZDdjNTI3NTkxYWUmaW5zaWQ9NTEwNw&ptn=3&fclid=e658a0c1-defd-11ec-a532-579bfbff64fd&u=a1aHR0cHM6Ly9taW5lY3JhZnQubmV0Lw&ntb=1
```

**How To Reproduce**
<!-- How can we reproduce this issue? (as minimally and as precisely as possible) -->

1. Make a search using Bing (`!bing minecraft` for example)
2. Read the links in the search results.

**Expected behavior**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

The link in my example should have said `https://www.minecraft.net/en-us`.

**Screenshots & Logs**
<!-- If applicable, add screenshots, logs to help explain your problem. -->

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17971474/170850550-968845b9-3ef3-4ed2-ab9c-5a8681365a79.png)

**Additional Context**

This bug also happens on every single public instance I tested on https://searx.space.

Use my settings.yml file.

use_default_settings:

title: ImportError for two functions from different required modules
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**

1.0.0

**How did you install Searx?**

Using the official manual found in [the wiki](https://searx.github.io/searx/admin/installation-searx.html).

**What happened?**
After following the installation documentation I tried to run `webapp.py` and experienced the following error:

```
ImportError: cannot import name 'soft_unicode' from 'markupsafe' (/home/searx/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/MarkupSafe-2.1.0-py3.9-linux-x86_64.egg/markupsafe/__init__.py)      
```

After manually downgrading `markupsafe` via `pip install markupsafe==2.0.1 --user` I ran `webapp.py` again and got the following error:

```
ImportError: cannot import name 'json' from 'itsdangerous' (/home/searx/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/itsdangerous-2.1.0-py3.9.egg/itsdangerous/__init__.py)
```

After manually downgrading `itsdangerous` via `pip install itsdangerous==2.0.1 --user` 

Both issues seem to be related to deprecations of functions / modules, at least according to what I could [find on Stackoverflow](https://serverfault.com/questions/1094062/error-from-itsdangerous-import-json-as-json-importerror-cannot-import-name-j).

**How To Reproduce**

* Follow the instructions for installing Searx as documented in [the wiki](https://searx.github.io/searx/admin/installation-searx.html)
* Try to run `webapp.py`

**Expected behavior**
After following the steps outlined in the documentation I can run Searx.

**Screenshots & Logs**

```

  File "/home/searx/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/Flask-1.1.2-py3.9.egg/flask/__init__.py", line 14, in <module>

  File "/home/searx/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/Jinja2-2.11.3-py3.9.egg/jinja2/defaults.py", line 3, in <module>
    from .filters import FILTERS as DEFAULT_FILTERS  # noqa: F401
  File "/home/searx/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/Jinja2-2.11.3-py3.9.egg/jinja2/filters.py", line 13, in <module>
    from markupsafe import soft_unicode
ImportError: cannot import name 'soft_unicode' from 'markupsafe' (/home/searx/.local/lib/python3.9/site-packages/MarkupSafe-2.1.0-py3.9-linux-x86_64.egg/markupsafe/__init__.py)

title: Can't use Tor SOCKS proxy but HTTP proxy works fine: TypeError: […] 'max_connections'
body:
**Version**
The `master` branch at commit 0248777f959ba9ee26fc8f1c367ea4ef2cb5d7cc

**How did you install Searx?**
https://searx.github.io/searx/admin/installation-searx.html#installation-basic

**What happened?**
When trying to use the Tor network via SOCKS proxy for outgoing search engine traffic, Searx throws the following error messages multiple times for a bunch of engines some seconds after startup and any search request will fail (`unexpected crash`):

~~~
ERROR:searx.engines:wikidata engine: Fail to initialize
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/engines/__init__.py", line 295, in engine_init
    init_fn(get_engine_from_settings(engine_name))
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/engines/wikidata.py", line 689, in init
    jsonresponse = send_wikidata_query(query)
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/engines/wikidata.py", line 134, in send_wikidata_query
    http_response = get(SPARQL_ENDPOINT_URL + '?' + urlencode({'query': query}), headers=get_headers())
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/network/__init__.py", line 105, in get
    return request('get', url, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/network/__init__.py", line 82, in request
    response = future.result(timeout)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/concurrent/futures/_base.py", line 432, in result
    return self.__get_result()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/concurrent/futures/_base.py", line 384, in __get_result
    raise self._exception
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/network/network.py", line 201, in request
    client = await self.get_client(**kwargs_clients)
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/network/network.py", line 165, in get_client
    max_redirects
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/network/client.py", line 184, in new_client
    retries)
  File "/usr/local/searx/src/searx/network/client.py", line 146, in get_transport_for_socks_proxy
    **TRANSPORT_KWARGS)
  File "/usr/local/searx/env/lib/python3.7/site-packages/httpx_socks/_async_transport.py", line 63, in __init__
    **kwargs,
TypeError: type object got multiple values for keyword argument 'max_connections'
~~~

**How To Reproduce**
I have the following proxy configuration in the `outgoing` section of my `settings.yml`  which inherits the default settings, and I can confirm that the Tor SOCKS proxy is listening on `127.0.0.1:9050` and works just fine with programs like `curl`.

~~~yaml
outgoing:
    proxies :
        http  : 'socks5h://127.0.0.1:9050'
        https : 'socks5h://127.0.0.1:9050'
~~~

What *does* work without a problem is using the Tor network via HTTP proxy instead of SOCKS proxy with the following configuration (you would need to set `HTTPTunnelPort 9060` in the `torrc`). Then the traffic is definitely flowing through the Tor network.

~~~yaml
outgoing:
    proxies :
        http  : 'http://127.0.0.1:9060'
        https : 'http://127.0.0.1:9060'
~~~

**Expected behavior**
Unless I didn't misunderstood or misconfigured something, it should be possible to use the Tor network via SOCKS proxy?

**Screenshots & Logs**
1. [Full log output after startup](https://github.com/searx/searx/files/8079328/searx.log)
2. [The installed `pip` packages](https://github.com/searx/searx/files/8079646/searx-env-packages.txt)
3. **The web interface after searching for something:**
    ![searx-unexpected-crash](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7452174/154257294-6e73429d-9b0e-4741-8e3a-32ccf4ccb34d.png)

title: Qwant engine QAnon results
body:
**Version of Searx**
1.0.0-297-f2f72575.

**How did you install Searx?**
Docker.

**What happened?**
When Qwant has no results for something, it displays tons of results containing the world “Q”, including QAnon related stuff.

**How To Reproduce**
1. Search for `DNTWLOCK` on Qwant.
2. Qwant will show no results.
3. Search for `DNTWLOCK` on Searx.
4. Searx will return a lot of results containing the letter Q alone.

**Expected behavior**
No results should show if Qwant has no results, and of course, no QAnon stuff either.

title: Startpage seems to be partially broken
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
`1.0 - f2f72575023b9a08081f6c87bf309f1f12fa9978`
**How did you install Searx?**
Official wiki with uwsgi
**What happened?**
Requests to startpage trigger their abuse protection. The strange thing is, that
I can use curl without problems on the same host (when I change the user agent).

**How To Reproduce**
I'm not 100% sure how to reproduce this  on other machines, as startpage seem to
work fine when I tried it with a searx docker instance running on my local PC. 

**Expected behavior**
Startpage should return search results, not the abuse protection page. 

**Additional context**
I tried setting the `User-Agent` header by modifying the engine, but it changed nothing.

title: Gigablast engine breaks after a couple of hours
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**

```
git log -1
commit db2e8fd8b25f6f4bf9e1500589c9e48b8039b0cf (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD)
Author: searx-bot <69454556+searx-bot@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Mon Nov 15 20:32:34 2021 +0100

    Update searx.data - update_wikidata_units.py (#3050)

    Co-authored-by: dalf <dalf@users.noreply.github.com>

``` 

**How did you install Searx?**
I installed it following the wiki. I pulled the repository from git. Using apache server.

**What happened?**
Gigablast engine stops working after a couple hours. It produces the following error: `exception : Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)`

I observed the following behaviour:

1. I run
    ```
    sudo -H systemctl restart apache2
    sudo -H service uwsgi restart searx
    ```
2. First search fails with the error
3. Next few searches run well
4. After some time the error appears with every search. Repeat with step 1.


**How To Reproduce**
Install searx, enable gigablast, use it for a couple of hours.

**Expected behavior**
Gigablast engine should not create errors.

**Screenshots & Logs**

`/var/log/uwsgi/app/searx.log` is full with this error:

```
ERROR:searx.search.processor.online:engine gigablast : exception : Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/searx/searx-src/searx/search/processors/online.py", line 139, in search
    search_results = self._search_basic(query, params)
  File "/usr/local/searx/searx-src/searx/search/processors/online.py", line 123, in _search_basic
    return self.engine.response(response)
  File "/usr/local/searx/searx-src/searx/engines/gigablast.py", line 93, in response
    response_json = loads(resp.text)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/json/__init__.py", line 348, in loads
    return _default_decoder.decode(s)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/json/decoder.py", line 337, in decode
    obj, end = self.raw_decode(s, idx=_w(s, 0).end())
  File "/usr/lib/python3.7/json/decoder.py", line 355, in raw_decode
    raise JSONDecodeError("Expecting value", s, err.value) from None
json.decoder.JSONDecodeError: Expecting value: line 1 column 1 (char 0)
```

**Additional context**
 I'm using Raspbian on Raspberry Pi 4B
This seems to be the same issue as this one: https://github.com/searx/searx/issues/2141
I opened a new issue as the old one doesn't seem to get any attention.

body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
<!-- If you are running on master branch using git execute this command
in order to fetch the latest commit ID:
```
git log -1
``` 
If you are using searx-docker then look at the bottom of the Searx page
and check for the version after "Powered by searx"

Please also stipulate if you are using a forked version of Searx and
include a link to the fork source code.
-->
searx version 1.0.0-297-f2f72575
**How did you install Searx?**
installed using the commands at https://searx.github.io/searx/admin/installation-docker.html
**What happened?**
```bash
❯ export PORT=80
docker pull searx/searx
docker run --rm -v ${PWD}/searx:/etc/searx -p $PORT:8080 -e BASE_URL=http://localhost:$PORT/ searx/searx

```

**How To Reproduce**
run the same commands outlined above

**Expected behavior**
running instance of searx

**Screenshots & Logs**
I have tried enabling debug mode via settings; however no additional information is displayed.

**Additional context**
I am runnning this on a Macbook Air M1. I don't think this has anything to do with it since python based docker images don't seem to have a problem otherwise. I have also successfully setup searx with the docker commands on my main desktop with ubuntu and it seems to work fine there.

title: One of the 5 updates commits from yesterday broke searx (it just fails to search)

-->
It was this one (bd9c03b4) at the time I opened this:

<!-- Did you install Searx using the official wiki or using searx-docker
or manually by executing the searx/webapp.py file? -->
searx-docker
**What happened?**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->

Just the bd9c03b4 version and try to search something

Search should work ;)

**Screenshots & Logs**
<!-- If applicable, add screenshots, logs to help explain your problem. -->

**Additional context**
<!-- Add any other context about the problem here. -->

I'll test it tomorrow which commit might have gone wrong if you don't find it meanwhile. 
EDIT: container logs don't show any error but i didn't enable any debug options. reverted to a880920d and everything is back to normal

title: ERROR:searx.webapp:server.secret_key is not changed. Please use something else instead of ultrasecretkey
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
4882a3c7a4bde5dfbb2a8c1aaa6a754685802ef4

**How did you install Searx?**
update script

**What happened?**

With this patch Searx shows an empty webpage. Log shows:

```
ERROR:searx.webapp:server.secret_key is not changed. Please use something else instead of ultrasecretkey
```
It looks like my `/etc/searx/settings.yml` is not loaded anymore (there a `server.secret_key` is defined). Reverting this patch
```
    # return check_settings_yml('settings.yml') or check_settings_yml('/etc/searx/settings.yml')
    return check_settings_yml('/etc/searx/settings.yml')
```
 let's the web page start up again.

**How To Reproduce**
Create an `/etc/searx/settings.yml` and fill it with rudimentary configs, e.g. `server.secret`

Starting web page

<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
<!-- If you are running on master branch using git execute this command
in order to fetch the latest commit ID:
```
commit 21d7efa6ca635a1835c2f10c0f3a1e9486f455db (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD)

Author: Noémi Ványi <kvch@users.noreply.github.com>

If you are using searx-docker then look at the bottom of the Searx page
and check for the version after "Powered by searx"

Please also stipulate if you are using a forked version of Searx and
include a link to the fork source code.

**How did you install Searx?**
<!-- Did you install Searx using the official wiki or using searx-docker
or manually by executing the searx/webapp.py file? -->
I installed following the official wiki and execute it as webapp.py file
**What happened?**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
An error message in the UI when selectin the "image" tab saying "unexpected crash" for google images:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38839719/140664872-73725420-7a8f-4444-994b-82a136080aa1.png)

**How To Reproduce**
<!-- How can we reproduce this issue? (as minimally and as precisely as possible) -->
Search for anything and then switch to image tab
**Expected behavior**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->
Google images returns results
**Screenshots & Logs**
<!-- If applicable, add screenshots, logs to help explain your problem. -->
ERROR:searx.search.processor.online:engine google images : exception : 'list' object has no attribute 'get'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/searx/searx-src/searx/search/processors/online.py", line 139, in search
    search_results = self._search_basic(query, params)
  File "/usr/local/searx/searx-src/searx/search/processors/online.py", line 109, in _search_basic

    params, supported_languages, language_aliases, False
  File "/usr/local/searx/searx-src/searx/engines/google.py", line 185, in get_lang_info
    ret_val['params']['lr'] = "lang_" + lang_list.get(lang_country, language)

title: Cannot parse selector Header in rules.json => All engines timing out
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
<!-- If you are running on master branch using git execute this command
in order to fetch the latest commit ID:
```
git log -1
``` 
If you are using searx-docker then look at the bottom of the Searx page
and check for the version after "Powered by searx"

Please also stipulate if you are using a forked version of Searx and
include a link to the fork source code.
-->
**How did you install Searx?**
`Searx-docker -> exact git instructions`

**What happened?**
Searx worked now it doesn't. Have no idea how to debug. Upon container restart I got this error with filtron:
`
2021/10/11 17:06:43 Cannot parse rules: Cannot parse selector 'Header:X-Forwarded-For=nslookup(check.searx.space
)': invalid expression
`
After removing the first rule in `rules.json` filtron goes up, but all the engines get http error. Timeout is set to 15s.

**How To Reproduce**
systemctl start searx-docker.service

**Expected behavior**
Searx to be working as it did since I did no changes to the configuration files. Maybe the docker filtron image changed and screwed something up in the background.

**Screenshots & Logs**
<!-- If applicable, add screenshots, logs to help explain your problem. -->

**Additional context**
Maybe dns isn't resolving properly in the container? Since searx only has wget preinstalled,
`wget 1.1.1.1` works, but
`wget google.com` doesn't.

Ping gives me `are you root?` errors even when starting `docker exec -it --user root searx sh`, so I can't test with it.

docker-compose.yml
```
version: '3.7'

services:

  filtron:
    container_name: searx_filtron
    hostname: searx_filtron
    image: dalf/filtron
    restart: unless-stopped
    ports:
      - "172.17.0.1:4040:4040"
      - "172.17.0.1:4041:4041"
    networks:
      external:
        ipv4_address: 10.20.0.10
    command: -listen 0.0.0.0:4040 -api 0.0.0.0:4041 -target searx:8080
    volumes:
      - ./rules.json:/etc/filtron/rules.json:rw
    read_only: true
    cap_drop:
      - ALL

  searx:
    container_name: searx
    hostname: searx
    image: searx/searx:latest
    restart: unless-stopped
    networks:
      external:
        ipv4_address: 10.20.0.11
    command: ${SEARX_COMMAND:-}
    volumes:
      - ./searx:/etc/searx:rw
    environment:
      - BIND_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:8080
      - BASE_URL=https://${SEARX_HOSTNAME:-localhost}
    cap_drop:
      - ALL
    cap_add:
      - CHOWN
      - SETGID
      - SETUID
      - DAC_OVERRIDE

networks:
  external:
    ipam:
      config:
        - subnet: 10.20.0.8/29
```

title: Query from Firefox address or search bars displays the searX search page instead of results
body:
**Version**
1.0.0-224-762c1c41

**Installation**
Docker pull from `searx/searx` running on a dedicated server - you may see it at https://search.cime.net

**How did you install Searx?**

searX lives behind a reverse Ngnix proxy that handles SSL termination for the cime.net domain.

```
# Ngnix SSL termination config:

... snip ...

    server {
        listen 80 default_server;
        listen [::]:80;
        server_name _;
        return 301 https://$host$request_uri;
    }

... snip ....

    server { 
        listen       443 ssl;
        server_name  search.cime.net;
        access_log   /var/log/nginx/search.access.log  main;
        error_log    /var/log/nginx/search.error.log;
        
        ssl_certificate_key         /etc/nginx/ssl/private/wildcard-cime_net.key;
        ssl_certificate             /etc/nginx/ssl/certs/cime_net-intermediate-bundle.crt;
        ssl_session_timeout         5m;
        ssl_ciphers                 "ECDHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES256-GCM-SHA384:DHE-RSA-AES128-GCM-SHA256:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-SHA384:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-SHA256:ECDHE-RSA-AES256-SHA:ECDHE-RSA-AES128-SHA:DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES128-SHA256:DHE-RSA-AES256-SHA:DHE-RSA-AES128-SHA:ECDHE-RSA-DES-CBC3-SHA:EDH-RSA-DES-CBC3-SHA:AES256-GCM-SHA384:AES128-GCM-SHA256:AES256-SHA256:AES128-SHA256:AES256-SHA:AES128-SHA:DES-CBC3-SHA:HIGH:!aNULL:!eNULL:!EXPORT:!DES:!MD5:!PSK:!RC4";
        ssl_protocols               TLSv1.2 TLSv1.3;
        ssl_session_cache           shared:SSL:10m;
        ssl_stapling                on;
        ssl_stapling_verify         on;
        ssl_prefer_server_ciphers   on;
  
        location / {
            proxy_pass      http://192.168.0.240:8809;
        }
    }
```

```
# docker-compose.yaml
version: 3
services:
    search_cime_net:
        container_name: search_cime_net
        environment:
            CONTAINER_DOMAIN_NAME: "cime.net"
        image: "searx/searx"
        ports:
            - "192.168.0.240:8809:8080"
        privileged: true
```
Made searX the default search engine in Firefox as described in _[Add or remove a search engine in Firefox](https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/add-or-remove-search-engine-firefox)_.

**What happened?**
The query from the Firefox address or search bars results in display of the searX landing page instead of a results page.

**How To Reproduce**
1. Enable searX as the default search engine
2. Enter a query on the address or search bar
3. See results

**Expected behavior**
searX would display search results.  Instead, it displays the main searX search page.

**Screenshots & Logs**
Query:  cookie recipes

Request: 

POST /search HTTP/1.1
Host: search.cime.net
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.15; rv:92.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/92.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Content-Length: 16
DNT: 1
Connection: keep-alive
Cookie: categories=general; language=en-US; locale=en; autocomplete=google; image_proxy=1; method=POST; safesearch=0; theme=oscar; results_on_new_tab=1; doi_resolver=oadoi.org; oscar-style=logicodev-dark; advanced_search=0; disabled_engines=; enabled_engines="yahoo__general\054reddit__images\054reddit__general"; disabled_plugins=; enabled_plugins=; tokens=
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
Sec-GPC: 1

Response:

HTTP/1.1 301 Moved Permanently
Server: nginx/1.21.3
Date: Tue, 28 Sep 2021 15:13:18 GMT
Content-Type: text/html
Content-Length: 169
Connection: keep-alive
Location: https://search.cime.net/search

**Additional context**
None.

title: No DuckDuckGo paging
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
0.18.0 and 1.0.0/1.0.0-1.0.0
<!-- If you are running on master branch using git execute this command
in order to fetch the latest commit ID:
```
git log -1
``` 
If you are using searx-docker then look at the bottom of the Searx page
and check for the version after "Powered by searx"

Please also stipulate if you are using a forked version of Searx and
include a link to the fork source code.
-->
**How did you install Searx?**
Via FreedomBox web-GUI.
<!-- Did you install Searx using the official wiki or using searx-docker
or manually by executing the searx/webapp.py file? -->
**What happened?**
When I configure DuckDuckGo as the only engine, there's only one page of results opposed to multiple pages on DuckDuckGo for the same search query. I have this on my own 0.18.0 instance and I tested 2 public vanilla 0.18.0 instances and 8 public vanilla 1.0.0/1.0.0-1.0.0 instances with the same result.
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->

**How To Reproduce**
1. Use a 0.18.0 or 1.0.0/1.0.0-1.0.0 instance of Searx.
2. Go to _Preferences_ > _Engines_.
3. Click _Disable all_.
4. Toggle _duckduckgo_ to on.
5. Click _save_.
6. Search for something that gives multiple pages of results on https://duckduckgo.com (eg. _test_).
<!-- How can we reproduce this issue? (as minimally and as precisely as possible) -->

**Expected behavior**
A _next page_ button at the bottom of the first page of search results to go to the next page.
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->

**Screenshots & Logs**
![Screenshot_2021-09-24 test - FreedomBox Web Search](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1261041/134629240-667436e7-2ccc-4500-89df-d6399d9d157a.png)
<!-- If applicable, add screenshots, logs to help explain your problem. -->

**Additional context**
I'm using the 0.18.0 version of Searx as it comes with FreedomBox. FreedomBox uses Debian's repositories and version 1.0.0 isn't in it yet. I'm fine with it as long it's safe, unless 1.0.0 will solve this issue, but it doesn't appear to do so.
<!-- Add any other context about the problem here. -->

**Previous (similar/related) closed issues**
#1677 and #847

title: Invalid Mortyhash Parameter
body:
Version: 1.0.0 with nginx 
Cloned from this repo.

**How did you install Searx?**
Installed using official scripts on Ubuntu 21.04

**What happened?**
Created Morty base64 key and added to settings.yml file (using command: openssl rand -base64 33). 

When attempting to get proxied results, get error:

```
Error: invalid "mortyhash" parameter
Warning! This instance does not support direct URL opening.
```

I confirmed in the morty.service file that the -key is the same as the one in settings.yml
Morty log shows no errors (except invalid hash parameter). 

**How To Reproduce**
Install using scripts.  

**Expected behavior**
Proxified results should open.

title: Google engine crashes when language selected
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**

1.0.0-185-efe730fb

**How did you install Searx?**

https://github.com/k8s-at-home/charts/tree/master/charts/stable/searx

with some configuration

**What happened?**

Searx engines `google-de` and `google-en` used to bring multi-language search support crash due to imperfect parameter/object passing within code.


**How To Reproduce**
<!-- How can we reproduce this issue? (as minimally and as precisely as possible) -->

configure engines:

```

title: unsafe permissions for files in docker container
body:
When inspecting the Docker container of searx I realized that the permissions of files in the container are unsafe. 

```
/usr/local/searx/searx # ls -la
total 224
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           25 Jul 16 10:19 .
drwxr-sr-x    1 searx    searx           19 Jul 16 10:19 ..
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         3105 Jul 16 10:12 __init__.py
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           36 Jul 21 15:09 __pycache__
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           57 Jul 16 10:19 answerers
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         3839 Jul 16 10:12 autocomplete.py
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           25 Jul 16 10:19 data
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           25 Jul 16 10:19 engines
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         3416 Jul 16 10:12 exceptions.py
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         2962 Jul 16 10:12 external_bang.py
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         2163 Jul 16 10:12 external_urls.py
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         3237 Jul 16 10:12 languages.py
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           25 Jul 16 10:19 metrology
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           25 Jul 16 10:19 network
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           25 Jul 16 10:19 plugins
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx        19928 Jul 16 10:12 preferences.py
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx        11902 Jul 16 10:12 query.py
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx        14327 Jul 16 10:12 results.py
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           58 Jul 16 10:19 search
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx        44182 Jul  5 17:47 settings.yml
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         4771 Jul 16 10:12 settings_loader.py
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         1026 Jul 16 10:12 settings_robot.yml
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           25 Jul 16 10:19 shared
drwxr-xr-x    1 searx    searx           35 Jul 16 10:12 static
drwxr-xr-x    5 searx    searx           51 Jul 16 10:12 templates
-rw-r--r--    1 searx    searx         3220 Jul 16 10:12 testing.py
```

As the process itself is running as user searx:searx it has the permission to change its own binaries it is running from. This is usually a setup you want to avoid at any cost as it provides a much higher attack surface to a process than necessary.

I suggest to install all those files owned by root making only absolutely needed cache and log directories writeable to the searx user.

title: Google engine almost always gets 429 (too many requests) response
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
Version `1.0.0` from the official `searx/searx` repo.

**How did you install Searx?**
I followed the official Wiki instructions and ran the install scripts to get a regular Filtron-Searx-Morty install.

**What happened?**
When running a query through Google, I almost always (let's say 9 times out of 10) get a 429 (too many requests) response from Google.

Inspecting logs from Searx (see screenshots section) shows that Searx indeed gets a 429 response from Google, redirecting to a URL in the form of `https://www.google.com/sorry/index?continue=foo`.

**How To Reproduce**
1. Setup a Searx instance as per the Wiki, following the Filtron-Searx-Motry install through util scripts.
2. Run a query with the Google engine activated, possibly forcing a Google-only request by using the `!go` shortcut.

**Expected behavior**
I expect to be able to get Google results properly when I'm not trying to DDoS it :-)

**Screenshots & Logs**
![searx_google_2_anonymized](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/74539800/122797558-e1929a80-d2bf-11eb-95e8-788208f009fe.png)

**Additional context**
My public IP and the public IP of the server hosting my Searx instance are not (to the best of my knowledge) being used to query Google **at all** outside of Searx..

This bug occurred since the very first request I sent using Searx. I setup Searx a couple days ago.

title: Documentation: manage.sh update_packages does not exist enymore
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
4828faaa0701a6982becebb8e223e0bbe10ce559

**How did you install Searx?**

Manually installed via quick install documentation, searx-src beside searx-pyenv.

**What happened?**

`update-searx.rst` must be updated concerning `manage` instead of `manage.sh`

Update according to  `update-searx.rst` is not possible:

```
    sudo -H -u searx -i
    (searx)$ git stash
    (searx)$ git pull origin master
    (searx)$ git stash apply
    (searx)$ ./manage.sh update_packages
```
`manage.sh` does not exist anymore (since f7706a5c7fa33f38b4759586b514d64ac659eca3) but there is no documentation
how to update python packages via `manage`

**How To Reproduce**

Try to execute all commands above

**Expected behavior**

`manage.sh update_packages` can be called. No I expect the right documentation via state of the art `manage`

title: Youtube_noapi engine returns no results due to cookie consent redirect
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
v1.0.0 commit ae122ea943f77600fd97556503c483dcd92e1e63 official Repo

**How did you install Searx?**
Manual installation via official guide

**What happened?**
When trying to use the youtube_noapi engine it fails with a generic "couldn't find any results" error.
Inspecting the logs shows that searx is being redirected to youtubes cookie consent site (https://consent.youtube.com).

This seems to happen only within the EU. I tested some European instances and found all of them had broken youtube searches while American ones seem fine.

**How To Reproduce**
1. Host/Use a searx instance within the EU
2. Make a request to the youtube_noapi engine (e.g. "!yt test")

**Expected behavior**
Results from youtubes search page should be displayed by searx.

**Actual behaviour**
No results are displayed.

**Screenshots & Logs**
`
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:Starting new HTTPS connection (1): www.youtube.com:443
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://www.youtube.com:443 "GET /results?search_query=test&page=1 HTTP/1.1" 302 0
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:Starting new HTTPS connection (1): consent.youtube.com:443
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:https://consent.youtube.com:443 "GET /m?continue=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.youtube.com%2Fresults%3Fsearch_query%3Dtest%26page%3D1&
gl=DE&m=0&pc=yt&uxe=48395746&hl=de&src=1 HTTP/1.1" 200 None
`

**Additional context**
The cookie consent site sets a "CONSENT" cookie which subsequently is sent with all requests to youtube.
Without this cookie, using a normal browser, one will always be redirected to the consent page.
This does not happen when using curl, seemingly because it doesn't send a browser User-Agent with it's requests.

**Potential solution**
Trying around i managed to fix this issue in 2 ways:
1. Setting the consent cookie manually in the engines request function. The cookie value is simply copied from the browser:
`params['cookies'] = {'CONSENT': "YES+cb.20210401-14-p0.de+F+512"}`
(The value differs depending on machine/user so the above one should only be used to infer the format.)
2. (Probably preferable) Setting an empty User-Agent in the engines request function:
`params['headers']['User-Agent'] = ""`

title: searx.webadapter and utils/standalone_searx.py issues
body:
<!-- PLEASE FILL THESE FIELDS, IT REALLY HELPS THE MAINTAINERS OF SEARX -->

**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
<!-- If you are running on master branch using git execute this command
in order to fetch the latest commit ID:
```
git log -1
``` 
If you are using searx-docker then look at the bottom of the Searx page
and check for the version after "Powered by searx"

Please also stipulate if you are using a forked version of Searx and
include a link to the fork source code.
--> 
Master branch, latest commit id: 6c01145, not using forked version
```
commit 6c0114567e7ba1b3f4a54327eddf658b7474ca58 (HEAD -> master, origin/master, origin/HEAD)
Merge: 5d5ecdb7 b2093a8b
Author: Noémi Ványi <kvch@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Sun Apr 11 14:46:59 2021 +0200

    Merge pull request #2744 from ColonisationCaptain/patch-1
    
    Correct typo/grammatical mistake in documentation
```
**How did you install Searx?**
<!-- Did you install Searx using the official wiki or using searx-docker
or manually by executing the searx/webapp.py file? -->

Installed using the official wiki: [Step by step installation](https://searx.github.io/searx/admin/installation-searx.html#step-by-step-installation). However, I want to use a standalone search, so I don't switch to the 'searx' user to run the program. I stayed in my personal user and ran the following in bash:

```
$ mkdir ~/standalone_searx
$ cd ~/standalone_searx
$ git clone https://github.com/searx/searx.git
$ cd searx/
$ conda activate dev_python3
$ python3 searx_extra/standalone_searx.py rain
```
Output (first bug):
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "searx_extra/standalone_searx.py", line 88, in <module>
    import searx.webadapter
ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'searx.webadapter'
```
Tried another option, a example from the [standalone_searx.py](https://github.com/searx/searx/blob/master/searx_extra/standalone_searx.py) file:
```
$ ipython
In [1]: import importlib
import json
import sys
import searx.engines
import searx.search
search_query = 'rain'
# initialize engines
searx.search.initialize()
# load engines categories once instead of each time the function called
engine_cs = list(searx.engines.categories.keys())
# load module
spec = importlib.util.spec_from_file_location(
    'utils.standalone_searx', 'utils/standalone_searx.py')
sas = importlib.util.module_from_spec(spec)
spec.loader.exec_module(sas)
# use function from module
prog_args = sas.parse_argument([search_query], category_choices=engine_cs)
search_q = sas.get_search_query(prog_args, engine_categories=engine_cs)
res_dict = sas.to_dict(search_q)
sys.stdout.write(json.dumps(
    res_dict, sort_keys=True, indent=4, ensure_ascii=False,
    default=sas.json_serial))
```
Output (second bug):
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
FileNotFoundError                         Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-151e19fdf7af> in <module>
      7     'utils.standalone_searx', 'utils/standalone_searx.py')
      8 sas = importlib.util.module_from_spec(spec)
----> 9 spec.loader.exec_module(sas)

~/anaconda3/envs/tfg/lib/python3.8/importlib/_bootstrap_external.py in exec_module(self, module)

~/anaconda3/envs/tfg/lib/python3.8/importlib/_bootstrap_external.py in get_code(self, fullname)

~/anaconda3/envs/tfg/lib/python3.8/importlib/_bootstrap_external.py in get_data(self, path)

FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'utils/standalone_searx.py'
```

**What happened?**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what the bug is. -->
**Bug 1:** I got the `ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'searx.webadapter'`. I don't know the reason and couldn't fix it so I tried another option (read after first bug output).

**Bug 2:** I got the `FileNotFoundError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: 'utils/standalone_searx.py'`. The reason is that the _standalone_searx.py_ file is currently located in _search_extra/_, not _utils/_. I suppose that the directory was ~~renamed~~ _moved_ from _utils_ to _search_extra_ and @dalf forgot to change the line 34 from `'utils.standalone_searx', 'utils/standalone_searx.py')` to `'utils.standalone_searx', 'searx_extra/standalone_searx.py')` in the commit b8cd326. This fix works for me.

**How To Reproduce**
<!-- How can we reproduce this issue? (as minimally and as precisely as possible) -->
Follow the instructions specified in _How did you install Searx?_.

**Expected behavior**
<!-- A clear and concise description of what you expected to happen. -->
I expect the program not to throw the error for the first bug. The second bug is easy to fix, but I don't know the reason of the first one.

**Screenshots & Logs**
<!-- If applicable, add screenshots, logs to help explain your problem. -->
N/A

**Additional context**
<!-- Add any other context about the problem here. -->
N/A

**Remediation**

**Bug 2:** Change the line 34 from `'utils.standalone_searx', 'utils/standalone_searx.py')` to `'utils.standalone_searx', 'searx_extra/standalone_searx.py')` for the [standalone_searx.py](https://github.com/searx/searx/blob/master/searx_extra/standalone_searx.py) file.

I would like to finish saying thanks to all the developers for building this amazing app, not only the members of Searx but also devs like @dalf for the contributions. This is one of the first issues I write so please tell me if you find something inappropriate or any suggestions for me to improve.

title: yggtorrent engine: Fail to initialize / does not work
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**

branch master

**How did you install Searx?**

    make run

Always get a _yggtorrent engine: Fail to initialize_ / e.g. [here in every build](https://github.com/searx/searx/pull/2611/checks#step:5:297))::

    ERROR:searx.engines:yggtorrent engine: Fail to initialize
    ....
    File "/home/runner/work/searx/searx/searx/engines/yggtorrent.py", line 42, in init
        resp = http_get(url, allow_redirects=False)
    ...
    raise SearxEngineCaptchaException(message='Cloudflare CAPTCHA', suspended_time=3600 * 24 * 15)

The cloudflare captcha comes from the init function of yggtorrent:

https://github.com/searx/searx/blob/e2fb50089219207f7e11bcfc049b48f2f4b9a6c8/searx/engines/yggtorrent.py#L39-L46

@unixfox do you have a clue how we can bypass  the captcha (at least in the init process)?

BTW: CAPTCHA problem is not limited to init proc / all `!ygg` queries result in _yggtorrent (CAPTCHA required)_ or even _Sorry!_
 after first CAPTCHA message.

title: search_url() templates/oscar/results.html  genarate url ignoredsettings['server']['base_url']
body: **Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx** `0.18.0-160-ab873980` **How did you install Searx?** nignx ``` server { server_name domian.org; location / { proxy_pass http://127.0.0.1:8080/; } } ``` docker ```base docker run -it -p 8080:8080 -e BASE_URL=https://domian.org/ searx/searx ``` **What happened?** Search Url is "127.0.0.1:8080" **How To Reproduce** 1. configure nignx as above 2. start docker 3. search anything **Expected behavior** Search Url is "domain.org" **Screenshots & Logs** **Additional context** in [templates/oscar/results.html ](https://github.com/searx/searx/blob/709dd960f125af17cffa10715d5bdef15018a918/searx/templates/oscar/results.html) line 10 ```python {%- macro search_url() %}{{ url_for('search', _external=True) }}?q={{ q|urlencode }}{% if selected_categories %}&categories={{ selected_categories|join(",") | replace(' ','+') }}{% endif %}{% if pageno > 1 %}&pageno={{ pageno }}{% endif %}{% if time_range %}&time_range={{ time_range }}{% endif %}{% if current_language != 'all' %}&language={{ current_language }}{% endif %}{% endmacro -%} ``` with `_external=True`, flask `url_for` will generate full url, the action to urljoin `settings['server']['base_url'] `will be invalid. ```python def url_for_theme(endpoint, override_theme=None, **values): if endpoint == 'static' and values.get('filename'): theme_name = get_current_theme_name(override=override_theme) filename_with_theme = "themes/{}/{}".format(theme_name, values['filename']) if filename_with_theme in static_files: values['filename'] = filename_with_theme url = url_for(endpoint, **values) if settings['server']['base_url']: if url.startswith('/'): url = url[1:] url = urljoin(settings['server']['base_url'], url) return url ``` ```python >>> settings['server']['base_url'] 'https://xxx.xxx.org/' >>> urljoin(settings['server']['base_url'], 'http://127.0.0.1:8080/search') 'http://127.0.0.1:8080/search' ```

```
root@vm-searx:~# cat /var/log/uwsgi/app/searx.log | grep "naver"
root@vm-searx:~# cat /var/log/uwsgi/app/searx.log | grep "nvr"

title: Integrated jobs (git workflows) also run on forks.
body:
For me it is not clear, is this a side effect or is there any use of?

By example: I have a fork and my master branch is a brand [see last commit on my master](https://github.com/return42/searx/commits/master).

Every time I rebase my master on searx/master the git workflow starts to run the tests and builds .. since it is a brand this job will fail and I got a mail with the subject:

    [return42/searx] Run failed: Integration - gh-pages (nnnnnnn)

It is not the mail that bothers me, it is the thought that the builds (in forks) might be a huge waste of energy without any ecological sense.

Thoughts?

title: Using more memory?
body:
Searx  5a511f0d620038b8e94c581bcfd3c987082b9414 commit id (0.18.0)
Installed as wiki

Increasing memory use compared to previous versions.
I admit I didn't upgrade for ages, but this version of searx seems to use much more memory over time than previous versions. At the moment around 406KB of memory. Not sure I'd ask if it's a leak (it almost never is), but previous versions didn't seem to retain memory like this. It seems to very slowly increase over time.

**How To Reproduce**
Run searx for a few weeks without restarting it and keep sending it queries.

**Expected behavior**
Less than 400KB of memory used for something that's basically sitting there doing nothing waiting for a query / webpage load. Pretty sure it didn't use this much memory a few months ago. Could be a library searx depends on being a glutton. But it's becoming an issue on a Pi 3b. It wasn't an issue a while back.

title: my settings.yml preferences are not being carried over
body:
Using the following docker installation guide on searx website I was able to get the search engine running without problems

```
export PORT=80

docker pull searx/searx

docker run --rm -d -v ${PWD}/searx:/etc/searx -p $PORT:8080 -e BASE_URL=http://localhost:$PORT/ searx/searx
```

however when changing some preferences on settings.yml all of the changes except instance_name were not being used, for example autocomplete which I changed from blank to "google" or default_lang being changed from blank to pt-BR (or just pt), neither of the two changes were transfered on the engine after restarting the docker.

title: Bug in external command engine, resulting in engine crash.
body:
**Version of Searx, commit number if you are using on master branch and stipulate if you forked Searx**
```
commit a0ddc27766271428d6f1f906c774cf6f5ccbf3fa (HEAD -> master)
Merge: 8c887382 cdceec1c
Author: Searx Service Account <searx@leandra.virtadpt.net>
Date:   Sat Dec 5 17:21:41 2020 -0800

    Merge branch 'master' of https://github.com/asciimoo/searx
```
**How did you install Searx?**
Installed using instructions from the official wiki, by hand.

**What happened?**
I went to the Searx page on my server and ran the query `!locate art bell mp3` after enabling the Locate search engine in `/opt/searx/searx/searx/settings.yml`.

**How To Reproduce**
Enable the Locate search engine in settings.yml thusly:

```
  - name: locate
    engine: command
    command: ['locate', '--existing', '--ignore-case', '{{QUERY}}']
    shortcut: locate
    tokens: []
    disabled: False
    delimiter:
        chars: ' '
        keys: ['line']
```
Restart Searx.

Execute a `!locate` search while watching Searx's output, either by running it by hand or using `journalctl -xf` to tail the systemd journal.

**Expected behavior**
Searx runs the `locate` command on the server and returns the results.

**Screenshots & Logs**
Logs (datestamp, hostname, and PID elided to prevent having to scroll back and forth repeatedly):
```
: Traceback (most recent call last):
:   File "/opt/searx/searx/searx/search.py", line 281, in search_one_offline_request_safe
:     search_results = search_one_offline_request(engine, query, request_params)
:   File "/opt/searx/searx/searx/search.py", line 274, in search_one_offline_request
:     return engine.search(query, request_params)
:   File "/opt/searx/searx/searx/engines/command.py", line 70, in search
:     cmd = _get_command_to_run(query)
:   File "/opt/searx/searx/searx/engines/command.py", line 83, in _get_command_to_run
:     params = shlex_split(query.decode('utf-8'))
: AttributeError: 'str' object has no attribute 'decode'
```

**Additional context**
Searx is being run as a system service, through systemd, with a searx.sh shell script:

```
#!/usr/bin/env bash

SEARX=/opt/searx/searx

# Change to the Searx installation directory.
cd $SEARX

# Initialize the Python virtual environment.
. env/bin/activate

# Start up Searx.
#python searx/webapp.py
uwsgi --ini searx.ini
```

Searx is being run with uwsgi to improve responsiveness.

Other searches on this instance are not impacted in this manner.

title: Can't use Searx as Search Engine for Firefox with Multi Account Extension enabled
body:
Hi.

As said in the title, with Firefox Multi-Account Containers extension enabled, searx does not work properly.

**What's happening**
If I am not focusing my Searx instance tab and if I try to make a search through Firefox address bar or Firefox search bar, the Searx instance opens but the search is not made. I just arrive on the Searx instance homepage.
However, once I am focusing the Searx instance tab, and if I try to make a search through the address bar or search bar of Firefox, the search is being made correctly.
If the tab is open but I am not focusing it, it does not work neither.


**How to reproduce**

1. Create a fresh Firefox instances (about:profiles) and launch Firefox with this profile
2. Go on a searx instance (I tried different instances but my reference instance will be searx.fmac.xyz/)
3. Add it as search engine (click on the three-dot menu, in address bar, then click on "add search engine")
4. (Optional) Enable it as default search engine in Firefox menus
5. Type `about:addons` in address bar and search for "multi".
6. Download Firefox Multi-Account Container extension
7. Manage containers to add a new one : Searx
8. Set up the searx instance (searx.fmac.xyz/) to always open through this container.
9. Make a search through Firefox search bar or address bar.

**Versions**
I used last Firefox Nightly build and Firefox 81.0. Both on Pop_OS 20.04.
As I said, I tried with fresh profiles with only multi-account containers open.

**More informations**
It's maybe not bound to Searx but Multi-Account containers seems to work properly with **every**
 other websites I am using since months. So that's why I opened this issue here.
I'll open another one on Multi-Account Containers.

title: [fix] simple theme: fix autocomplete
body:
## What does this PR do?

AJAX requests send the X-Requested-With HTTP header,
so searx.webapp.autocompleter returns the results with the expected data format.

## Why is this change important?

Since PR #2127, with the simple theme, autocomplete doesn't work 

## How to test this PR locally?

1. Use the simple
1. Try autocomplete in the form
1. Check it is working
1. Add searx as the default engine
1. Check autocomplete is working (in the browser search bar)

## Author's checklist

<!-- additional notes for reviewiers -->

## Related issues

Related to #2127
Close #2203

title: [fix] searx.utils.HTMLTextExtractor: invalid HTML don't raise an Exception
body:
## What does this PR do?

searx.utils.HTMLTextExtractor :
* without this PR, invalid HTML raise an ```Exception```: https://github.com/searx/searx/blob/272158944bf13503e2597018fc60a00baddec660/searx/utils.py#L112
* with this PR, invalid HTML raises a dedicated exception, then ```html_to_text``` can return the partial content.

## Why is this change important?

The ```Exception``` ends up to a HTTP Error 500 for the user.

## How to test this PR locally?

* See the new tests in tests/unit/test_utils.py

## Author's checklist

<!-- additional notes for reviewiers -->

## Related issues

Close #2188

title: 500 internal error for json data from some searches
body:
For some searches with searx I receive an 500 internal error when trying to access the json data (or csv or rss). To reproduce this try the following steps:

1. Search for `Maya_sculpture-71.893.4` e.g. https://searx.xyz/?q=Maya_sculpture-71.893.4
2. Click on the `json` button. to download the results as json data.

This leads to the 500 error. However, most other searches work well and also the json data can be downloaded. Only with this very specific search and few others I have experienced this problem.

Does anyone see why this causes a problem? How can this been solved?

title: The docker image no longer runs in k8s
body:
Due to a change in the docker entrypoint script in [this PR](https://github.com/searx/searx/pull/2099), the docker image no longer runs in k8s (the help function gets called and then the script exits).  I'm using microk8s on ubuntu, if that helps.

I'm not sure how important kubernetes support is, so I'm opening an issue versus a PR.

title: bangs.json is undistributable
body:
Hi,

I was just packaging the new searx release 0.17.0 (thanks for that!) for the Debian distribution. I noticed that the file `bangs.json` contains several favicons as `data:image/png;base64,...`. I doubt that you have the copyright on those icons? What is the copyright situation on them? I suppose that they are not distributed under a free license?

Assuming the latter, we currently have to completely remove `bangs.json` from the Debian package because patching out the offending favicons would still be a copyright violation because the copyrighted material would then be part of the patch removing them.

Can you advise for a better solution than shipping an empty `bangs.json`?

Thanks!

cheers, josch

title: [fix] external_bang - UnicodeDecodeError: 'ascii' codec can't decode
body:
Python's default encoding depends on the platform, set (python) default encoding
UTF-8 in uwsgi ini files:

    LANG=C.UTF-8
    LANGUAGE=C.UTF-8
    LC_ALL=C.UTF-8

title: Searching images for "hey" on any searx instance reporting 0.16.0-63-9a2f26d9 will cause a 500.
body:
To clarify on the title, this is an issue with all searx instances reporting version 0.16.0-63-9a2f26d9 (I assume those who use a prebuilt docker image), and some instances reporting 0.16.0 but not all. 

To reproduce:

- Go to any searx instance reporting 0.16.0-63-9a2f26d9
- Type "hey" with any capitalization (other three letter strings do not work)
- You can be using either GET or POST, and you can either search in general and click over to images, or search for images directly.
- Get error.

Here is a short [video](https://lbda.net/9FQ.mp4) of this being performed on 4 instances reporting 0.16.0-63-9a2f26d9 on [searx.space](https://searx.space).

title: templates: use the GIT_URL value instead of https://asciimoo.github.io/searx/
body:
In the templates, ```https://asciimoo.github.io/searx/``` should not be hard coded, it should use the [GIT_URL](https://github.com/asciimoo/searx/blob/master/Makefile#L3) value.

I'm not sure how to do that without adding a setting or file since GIT_URL is an environment variable declare in Makefile.

Related to https://github.com/asciimoo/searx/issues/1897

Lines in the templates:

title: Answerers only return usable results from a web browser and as a JSON document.
body:
When writing up a tutorial on how to use Searx's answerers, I noticed that they only return usable results when accessed through a web browser (as one would expect), and from the API when `format=json` is specified in the URL.  Requesting an RSS feed does not return an answer at all:
```
{14:39:28 @ Sun Mar 08}
[drwho @ windbringer ~] () $ curl https://localhost:8888/?q=min%205%2010%2015%2017%2023\&format=rss
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<rss version="2.0"
     xmlns:opensearch="http://a9.com/-/spec/opensearch/1.1/"
     xmlns:atom="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom">
  <channel>
    <title>Searx search: min 5 10 15 17 23</title>
    <link>http://localhost:8888/?q=min 5 10 15 17 23</link>
    <description>Search results for "min 5 10 15 17 23" - searx</description>
    <opensearch:totalResults>0</opensearch:totalResults>
    <opensearch:startIndex>1</opensearch:startIndex>
    <opensearch:itemsPerPage>0</opensearch:itemsPerPage>
    <atom:link rel="search" type="application/opensearchdescription+xml" href="http://localhost:8888/opensearch.xml"/>
    <opensearch:Query role="request" searchTerms="min 5 10 15 17 23" startPage="1" />
  </channel>
</rss>
```
Similarly, requesting CSV output returns nothing useful:
```
{14:51:26 @ Sun Mar 08}
[drwho @ windbringer ~] () $ curl https://localhost:8888/?q=min%205%2010%2015%2017%2023\&format=csv
title,url,content,host,engine,score
```
While it does kind of make sense that this could be the case, it's also misleading because they're listed in the Links box of the default theme under "Download results."  If they're not valid options they probably shouldn't be there.  If they are valid, those features are broken and might need to be fixed.

title: Problem with lobste.rs (and possibly other search engines): timeout
body:
**Issue:**

When running a search, _lobste.rs_ fails for me. In the results page, I get notified that 
```
"Engines cannot retrieve results: lobste.rs (timeout)".
```
in _/var/log/uwsgi/uwsgi.log_ it looks like this: 
```
DEBUG:urllib3.connectionpool:Starting new HTTPS connection (2): lobste.rs:443
WARNING:searx.search:engine timeout: lobste.rs
ERROR:searx.search:engine lobste.rs : HTTP requests timeout(search duration : 8.756943225860596 s, timeout: 8.0 s) : ReadTimeout
```

In my _settings.yml_, I have the following settings:
```
  - name : lobste.rs
    engine : xpath
    search_url : https://lobste.rs/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q={query}&what=stories&order=relevance
    results_xpath : //li[contains(@class, "story")]
    url_xpath : .//span[@class="link"]/a/@href
    title_xpath : .//span[@class="link"]/a
    content_xpath : .//a[@class="domain"]
    categories : it
    shortcut : lo
    timeout : 10.0
```

But checking prefs from web UI looks like this:
![img](https://imgur.com/g5za1Zm.png)


**Expected result**
- lobste.rs should respect the timeout set in _settings.yml_ and thereby not overrun the max timeout

**Steps to reproduce**
- Activate lobste.rs in prefs
- run any search query


**Version**
- docker image searx/searx:latest (0.15.0-186-42d5e2c0)

title: Searx Doesn't Start Debian 10
body:
After following the installation guide 
https://asciimoo.github.io/searx/dev/install/installation.html
and confirming that everything works when starting searx manually with

> python searx/webapp.py

And checking my nginx reverse proxy.
Doing it this way works 100%, however when I attempt to use uwsgi to demonize the process it doesn't actually start.
My uwsgi log shows 

> Tue Aug  6 04:10:59 2019 - added /usr/local/searx/ to pythonpath.
Tue Aug  6 04:10:59 2019 - spawned uWSGI master process (pid: 31839)
Tue Aug  6 04:10:59 2019 - spawned uWSGI worker 1 (pid: 31846, cores: 1)
Tue Aug  6 04:10:59 2019 - spawned uWSGI worker 2 (pid: 31847, cores: 1)
Tue Aug  6 04:10:59 2019 - spawned uWSGI worker 3 (pid: 31848, cores: 1)
Tue Aug  6 04:10:59 2019 - spawned uWSGI worker 4 (pid: 31850, cores: 1)
Tue Aug  6 04:11:01 2019 - WSGI app 0 (mountpoint='') ready in 2 seconds on interpreter 0x55def990df50 pid: 31846 (default app)
Tue Aug  6 04:11:01 2019 - WSGI app 0 (mountpoint='') ready in 2 seconds on interpreter 0x55def990df50 pid: 31848 (default app)
Tue Aug  6 04:11:01 2019 - WSGI app 0 (mountpoint='') ready in 2 seconds on interpreter 0x55def990df50 pid: 31847 (default app)
Tue Aug  6 04:11:01 2019 - WSGI app 0 (mountpoint='') ready in 2 seconds on interpreter 0x55def990df50 pid: 31850 (default app)

and my nginx error log shows

> 2019/08/06 04:10:13 [error] 31469#31469: *1 connect() failed (111: Connection refused) while connecting to upstream, client: {removed}, server: localhost, request: "GET /searx/ HTTP/1.1", upstream: "http://127.0.0.1:8888/searx/", host: "{removed}"

This leads me to believe it's an issue directly related to uwsgi.

For now I will use a work-around by putting the process into tmux, however I would like to figure out why uwsgi is failing.

title: Results fetched from docmentation sites are shown as raw HTML
body:
Search results which are fetched from [git-scm](https://git-scm.com) is in HTML language.


![git2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28824347/61836998-5362cf00-ae72-11e9-9a23-a83ec69fad69.png)

Whereas, on [git-scm](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-add) result is shown as follows

![git-scm](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28824347/61837439-5363ce80-ae74-11e9-943d-b8b24dd355a8.png)


Search any query related to git (like git add, git commit, etc), if it's fetched from git-scm, it should be in HTML language, inside the info box.

**Edit:**

Seems like, problem is not only with git-scm; but with most of the documentation site related to programming language. For instance try these searches:

* Python3 docs: [!ddd python math.sqrt](https://searx.me/?q=%21ddd%20python%20math.sqrt&categories=none&language=en-US)

title: fix: Remove english shell dependency in manage.sh script
body:
The current `manage.sh` script checks its internal methods using:

```
[ $(command -V "$ACTION" | grep ' function$')" = "" ]
```

A problem occurs when your shell locale is not english. Mine is french for example and `command -V update_packages` will return:

```
update_packages est une fonction
update_packages ()
{
    pip install --upgrade pip;
    pip install --upgrade setuptools;
    pip install -r "$BASE_DIR/requirements.txt"
}
```

`fonction` being different than `function`, the script does not work at all.

This pull requests replace the `command` by a `sed` one, which expect than the internal method will all use the same syntax. That way, method check is now language independant. However, the sed check is very naive for now and would need improvement the day more methods (or "private" methods) will be added to the script.

title: Pass morty key as bytes object to hmac
body:
Currently, the example for `settings.yml` contains:

```
# searx supports result proxification using an external service: https://github.com/asciimoo/morty
# uncomment below section if you have running morty proxy
#result_proxy:
#    url : http://127.0.0.1:3000/
#    key : your_morty_proxy_key
```

This means that the `key` parameter is stored as a `str` Python object. But the `hmac()` function requires a `bytes` object instead:

https://docs.python.org/3/library/hmac.html#hmac.new

When following the example as it is written above, searx will throw the following error:

```
[...]
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/searx/webapp.py", line 284, in proxify
    hashlib.sha256).hexdigest()
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/hmac.py", line 144, in new
    return HMAC(key, msg, digestmod)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/hmac.py", line 42, in __init__
    raise TypeError("key: expected bytes or bytearray, but got %r" % type(key
).__name__)
TypeError: key: expected bytes or bytearray, but got 'str'
```

One possible workaround is to tag the key with `!!binary` in `settings.yml` like so:

```
    url : http://127.0.0.1:3000/
    key : !!binary |
      eW91cl9tb3J0eV9wcm94eV9rZXk=
```

The string `eW91cl9tb3J0eV9wcm94eV9rZXk=` is a base64 encoded version of `your_morty_proxy_key`. So if morty is started with `-key your_morty_proxy_key` then the above searx setting will work.

Please adapt the example in `settings.yml` to reflect this requirement of supplying the `key` parameter as binary data.

title: Is Bing feeding garbage results to searx?
body:
I've noticed most results from bing are irrelevant. Not even based on any of the words I use on my queries.

For example, the query "youtube dash stream full hd" returns as a frist results a tesco link to buy a tv. I guess the "full hd" triggered that maybe, but if you scroll down the 7th result is a link to the FBI podcast (???). For that particular query out of 7 bing results only 1 is maybe relevant.

Here are other query examples that yield garbage resuts.

Query: easy privacy list . 1st result is a page called muscchoice, completely irrelevant. 3rd bing result is a page called growweedeasy, again nothing to do with my query. out of 10 bing results for this query once again maybe just one is partially relevant.

Query: adblock plus rules div tag. This time the first result is correct from both bing and google, but the 4th one (3rd bing result) is for a page called globolister. with the title "vote for icefilmsdotinfo" which is unrelated to my query

Query: "reply all" podcasts. For this one I quoted the term "reply all" which is the name of the podcast. and the very first result from bing point to buzzfeed podcast. I feel like this is just plain advertisement


Query: can vitamin c audio. For a more confusing term, since the the query contains words used in other contexts, the first bing result links to amazonand what  I'm actually looking for is a song. google gets it right .

Query: bert jansch "needle of death" lyrics. Another quoted query, the first result is from a page called popmatters talking about another song, and it doesn't even contain the lyrics. the 3rd link is from a newspaper that makes a small reference to the singer,nothing else. 4th result is for a page called michaelchapman, irrelevant. Out of 6 bing results, again, maybe a couple are partially relevant, none are what I'm looking for.


I could keep adding queries but I think I made my point very clear. In my opinion Bing is feeding garbage to searx. Or maybe it is just that bing is that bad. So I would like to request the removal of Bing as a default search engine
